data.name: helpApp
data.value:
Info about a setting: 
Move the cursor over a setting to view a brief explanation 
Analyze (Button): Determines which settings are enabled and configured on your system or not. NO system changes are done yet! 
Apply selected (Button): This will enable all selected settings. 
Revert selected (Button): This will restore the default Windows 10 settings. 
Configured (State): This indicates your privacy is protected. 
Not Configured (State): This indicates that the Windows 10 settings are in place.

data.name: infoApp
data.value:
The open source Windows 10 privacy settings app.
This is in no way related to Microsoft and a completely independent project.
All infos and credits about this project on \tgithub.com/builtbybel/privatezilla
You can also follow me on \ttwitter.com/builtbybel
(C#) 2021, Builtbybel
data.comment: About the app Add translation credits here!

data.name: LblStatus
data.value: Press Analyze to check for configured settings.

data.name: msgAppCompatibility
data.value: You are running Privatezilla on a system older than Windows 10. Privatezilla is limited to Windows 10 ONLY.

data.name: PSSaveAs
data.value: Save current script as new preset script

data.name: releaseUnofficial
data.value: You are using an unoffical version of Privatezilla.

data.name: releaseUpdateAvailable
data.value: There is a new version available #

data.name: releaseUpdateAvailableURL
data.value: \r\nDo you want to open the @github/releases page?

data.name: releaseUpToDate
data.value: There are currently no updates available.

data.name: settingsAppsAccountInfo
data.value: Disable app access to account info

data.name: settingsAppsAppNotificationsInfo
data.value: The Action Center in Windows 10 collects and shows notifications and alerts from traditional Windows applications and system notifications, alongside those generated from modern apps.\nNotifications are then grouped in the Action Center by app and time.\nThis setting will disable all notifications from apps and other senders in settings.

data.name: settingsAppsBackgroundAppsInfo
data.value: Windows 10 apps have no more permission to run in the background so they can't update their live tiles, fetch new data, and receive notifications.

data.name: settingsAppsCallHistory
data.value: Disable app access to call history

data.name: settingsAppsCellularData
data.value: Disable app access to cellular data

data.name: settingsAppsCellularDataInfo
data.value: Some Windows 10 devices have a SIM card and/or eSIM in them that lets you connect to a cellular data network (aka: LTE or Broadband), so you can get online in more places by using a cellular signal.\nIf you do not want any apps to be allowed to use cellular data, you can disable it with this setting.

data.name: settingsAppsEyeGaze
data.value: Disable app access to eye tracking

data.name: settingsAppsEyeGazeInfo
data.value: Disable app access to eye-gaze-based interaction

data.name: settingsAppsFileSystem
data.value: Disable app access to file system

data.name: settingsAppsFileSystemInfo
data.value: This setting will disable app access to file system. Some apps may be restricted in their function or may no longer work at all.

data.name: settingsAppsOtherDevices
data.value: Disable app access to other devices

data.name: settingsAppsTrackingAppsInfo
data.value: This allows you to quickly have access to your list of Most used apps both in the Start menu and when you search your device."

data.name: settingsBloatwareRemoveUWPAllInfo
data.value: This will remove all built-in apps except Microsoft Store.

data.name: settingsBloatwareRemoveUWPDefaultsInfo
data.value: This will search and remove pre-installed bloatware apps fully automatically.\nThe matching takes place on the basis of a community list

data.name: settingsCortanaDisableBingInfo
data.value: Windows 10, by default, sends everything you search for in the Start Menu to their servers to give you results from Bing search.

data.name: settingsCortanaDisableCortanaInfo
data.value: Cortana is Microsoft's virtual assistant that comes integrated into Windows 10.\nThis setting will disable Cortana permanently and prevent it from recording and storing your search habits and history.

data.name: settingsCortanaUninstallCortanaInfo
data.value: This will uninstall the new Cortana app on Windows 10, version 2004.

data.name: settingsDefenderDisableSmartScreenStoreInfo
data.value: Windows Defender SmartScreen Filter helps protect your device by checking web content (URLs) that Microsoft Store apps use.

data.name: settingsEdeAutoFillCreditInfo
data.value: Microsoft Edge's AutoFill feature lets users auto complete credit card information in web forms using previously stored information.

data.name: settingsEdgeBackgroundInfo
data.value: On the new Chromium version of Microsoft Edge, extensions and other services can keep the browser running in the background even after it's closed.

data.name: settingsEdgeBlockEdgeRollout
data.value: Block Installation of New Microsoft Edge

data.name: settingsEdgeBlockEdgeRolloutInfo
data.value: This will block Windows 10 Update Force Installing of the new Chromium-based Microsoft Edge web browser if it's not installed already on the device.

data.name: settingsEdgeDisableSyncInfo
data.value: This setting will disable synchronization of data using Microsoft sync services.

data.name: settingsGamingGameBarInfo
data.value: This setting will disable the Windows Game Recording and Broadcasting.

data.name: settingsGamingGameBarInfoInfo
data.value: This will turn off tailored experiences with relevant tips and recommendations by using your diagnostics data. Many people would call this telemetry, or even spying.

data.name: settingsPrivacyBlockSuggestedAppsInfo
data.value: This will block the Suggested Apps that occasionally appear on the Start menu.

data.name: settingsPrivacyDiagnosticDataInfo
data.value: This will turn off tailored experiences with relevant tips and recommendations by using your diagnostics data. Many people would call this telemetry, or even spying.

data.name: settingsPrivacyDisableAds
data.value: Disable Advertising ID for Relevant Ads

data.name: settingsPrivacyDisableAdsInfo
data.value: Windows 10 comes integrated with advertising. Microsoft assigns a unique identificator to track your activity in the Microsoft Store and on UWP apps to target you with relevant ads.

data.name: settingsPrivacyDisableBiometricsInfo
data.value: Windows Hello biometrics lets you sign in to your devices, apps, online services, and networks using your face, iris, or fingerprint.

data.name: settingsPrivacyDisableCEIPInfo
data.value: The Customer Experience Improvement Program (CEIP) is a feature that comes enabled by default on Windows 10, and it secretly collects and submits hardware and software usage information to Microsoft.

data.name: settingsPrivacyDisableCompTelemetryInfo
data.value: This process is periodically collecting a variety of technical data about your computer and its performance and sending it to Microsoft for its Windows Customer Experience Improvement Program.

data.name: settingsPrivacyDisableFeedbackInfo
data.value: Windows 10 may also pop up from time to time and ask for feedback.

data.name: settingsPrivacyDisableHEIPInfo
data.value: The Help Experience Improvement Program (HEIP) collects and send to Microsoft information about how you use Windows Help. This might reveal what problems you are having with your computer.

data.name: settingsPrivacyDisableLocationInfo
data.value: Wherever you go, Windows 10 knows you're there. When Location Tracking is turned on, Windows and its apps are allowed to detect the current location of your computer or device.

data.name: settingsPrivacyDisableMSExperimentsInfo
data.value: In certain builds of Windows 10, users could let Microsoft experiment with the system to study user preferences or device behavior. This allows Microsoft to “conduct experiments” with the settings on your PC and should be disabled with this setting.

data.name: settingsPrivacyDisableTelemetryInfo
data.value: This will prevent Windows from collecting usage information and setting diagnostic data to Basic, which is the lowest level available for all consumer versions of Windows 10.\nThe services diagtrack & dmwappushservice will also be disabled.\nNOTE: Diagnostic Data must be set to Full to get preview builds from Windows-Insider-Program!

data.name: settingsPrivacyDisableTimelineInfo
data.value: This collects a history of activities you've performed, including files you've opened and web pages you've viewed in Edge.\nIf Timeline isn’t for you, or you simply don’t want Windows 10 collecting your sensitive activities and information, you can disable Timeline completely with this setting.\nNote: A system reboot is required for the changes to take effect.

data.name: settingsPrivacyDisableTipsInfo
data.value: You will no longer see Windows Tips, e.g. Spotlight and Consumer Features, Feedback Notifications etc.

data.name: settingsPrivacyDisableTipsLockScreen
data.value: Disable Ads and Links on Lock Screen

data.name: settingsPrivacyDisableTipsLockScreenInfo
data.value: This setting will set your lock screen background options to a picture and turn off tips, fun facts and tricks from Microsoft.

data.name: settingsPrivacyDisableWiFiInfo
data.value: You should at least stop your PC from sending your Wi-Fi password.

data.name: settingsPrivacyGetMoreOutOfWindows
data.value: Disable Get Even More Out of Windows

data.name: settingsPrivacyGetMoreOutOfWindowsInfo
data.value: Recent Windows 10 versions occasionally display a nag screen "Get Even More Out of Windows" when you sign-in to your user account. If you find it annoying, you can disable it with this setting.

data.name: settingsPrivacyHandwritingDataInfo
data.value: If you don’t want Windows to know and record all unique words that you use, like names and professional jargon, just enable this setting.

data.name: settingsPrivacyInstalledAppsInfo
data.value: When you sign-in to a new Windows 10 profile or device for the first time, chance is that you notice several third-party applications and games listed prominently in the Start menu.\nThis setting will block automatic Installation of suggested Windows 10 apps.

data.name: settingsPrivacyInventoryCollectorInfo
data.value: The Inventory Collector inventories applications files devices and drivers on the system and sends the information to Microsoft. This information is used to help diagnose compatibility problems.\nNote: This setting has no effect if the Customer Experience Improvement Program is turned off. The Inventory Collector will be off.

data.name: settingsPrivacySuggestedContent
data.value: Block suggested content in Settings app

data.name: settingsPrivacySuggestedContentInfo
data.value: To help new Windows 10 users to learn new features of Windows 10, Microsoft has started showing suggested content via a huge banner in Windows 10 Setting Apps.

data.name: settingsSecurityDisablePasswordInfo
data.value: The password reveal button can be used to display an entered password and should be disabled with this setting.

data.name: settingsSecurityWindowsDRM
data.value: Disable DRM in Windows Media Player

data.name: settingsSecurityWindowsDRMInfo
data.value: If the Windows Media Digital Rights Management should not get access to the Internet (or intranet) for license acquisition and security upgrades, you can prevent it with this setting.

data.name: settingsUpdatesBlockMajorUpdatesInfo
data.value: This setting called "TargetReleaseVersionInfo" prevents Windows 10 feature updates from being installed until the specified version reaches the end of support.\nIt will specify your currently used Windows 10 version as the target release version of Windows 10 that you wish the system to be on (supports only Pro and enterprise versions).

data.name: settingsUpdatesDisableSafeguardsInfo
data.value: Microsoft uses diagnostic data to determine whether devices that use Windows Update are ready for a feature update in order to ensure a smooth experience.\nWhen Microsoft determines a device is not ready to update due to a known issue, a safeguard hold (also known as a compatibility hold or update block) is generated to delay the device's upgrade and protect the end-user experience.\nThis setting will opt out of safeguard protections allowing you to bypass any feature upgrade blocks.

data.name: settingsUpdatesDisableUpdatesInfo
data.value: This will notify when updates are available, and you decide when to install them.

data.name: settingsUpdatesUpdateSharingInfo
data.value: Windows 10 lets you download updates from several sources to speed up the process of updating the operating system. This will disable sharing your files by others and exposing your IP address to random computers.

data.name: statusUndoSettings
data.value: Do you really want to revert all selected settings to Windows 10 default state?

data.name: TxtPSInfo
data.value:
Welcome to the Scripting Editor, which allows you to apply third-party script files and custom settings in form of PowerShell scripts and templates (bundled scripts).
Select a script to view it's description.
To check the code for vulnerabilities click on "View code".
To obtain new objects (templates, scripts etc.) visit the Marketplace in the upper right menu.
